captions.text: Gooood morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So, we're undergoing a pretty significant
office reorganization project, and along the

way I found a lot of documents from my past
like, uh, this old picture of me.

Good news, little me. Your braces are going
to come off! In six more years.

I also found this somewhat newer picture of
me. I'm not sure if this is a photograph,
but it's definitely realistic.

And from 2006, my favorite fan mail ever,
"In regards to Looking For Alaska I can honestly

say that after putting your book down I felt
a feeling that I had not felt before. It was

not a sickness, like I was going to throw
up. Or a feeling like I had to take a crap
or anything. But I felt something."

Your book made me feel something, man. Not
the two main things I feel: the urges to defecate
and vomit, but something new.

And Hank, I also found, from way back in 1994,
some of my report cards.

This is from my junior year of high school,
Hank. I got a C- in Latin, "John went into

a tailspin in this course during the last
6 weeks. He missed too many classes and seldom
was prepared for the daily lesson."

Yeah, that's Latin; that's a dead language.
This is from my, uh, French - got a B- in

French, not to brag. "It's safe to say that
John underachieved this year." Hmm.

American history, I got a B, "John managed
to get to class more often during the final

trimester, and his grade came up - a bit."
That wasn't necessary, to say "A bit." Could

have just ended it at my grade came up. It's
technically accurate.

I got a C- in Pre-Calc, which frankly, was
probably generous. In chemistry, C. And in

English I got a, uh, C-, "Incredible potential
as an English student, but he's reached a
juncture where he just can't mail it in anymore."

Hank, I don't talk much about what a terrible
student I was in high school. I think partly

because I'm still embarrassed about it, 20
years later. I did miss a lot of classes,

you know, because they were early, or because
they conflicted with my schedule of smoking
cigarettes in the woods.

But even when I attended class, I was still
a pretty terrible student.

Hank, you know how you become the third best
C-student in the entire state of Alabama at

academic decathlon? First by getting terrible
grades so you're not an A or B student.

And that's who I was in high school. I underachieved,
and I skipped classes, and I didn't do my

homework, and I didn't do the reading, and
I was always behind and stressed out. Meanwhile,

Hank, you were getting great grades, and not
smoking cigarettes, and then you'd get a scholarship
to college and everything.

Anyway, Hank, coming across these report cards
made me think a couple things. The first is

that I was incredibly lucky. Like I didn't
just get a second chance -- I got hundreds

of chances. And even though I was a crap student,
I still had excellent teachers who continued

to believe in me despite my not giving them
a reason to.

The other thing these old report cards made
me think about, Hank, was this: High school

is not destiny. It's part of life, but I feel
like when you're in high school, people act

like it's the most important thing you'll
ever do, and like the whole course of your
life is being decided.

But at least so far as I can tell, the course
of your life isn't decided. Ever. Most of

the time it's not like there's one fork in
the road, and you choose one, or you choose

the other. There are hundreds of forks in
the road every day that you're alive.

College is also not destiny. For the record,
I was a much better college student than I
was a high school student.

Also your 20s are not destiny! Your 30s are
not destiny! Like, destiny is not something

that happens all at once. It's something that
happens only in retrospect.

Hank, when I was in high school, I thought
I was just, kind of, a screw up. You know?

But in the end, Hank, people aren't just one
thing. Like I WAS a screw up, but I was also
a pretty good reader.

And looking at those old report cards, I just
want to thank my teachers for knowing that

I wasn't just a screw up - even when I didn't
know it.
Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

title: Who I Was in High School

comments.author: Olga Shaw

comments.text:
I didn't go to a good high school. I was there from Year 1 (It was a year 1 
to 12 school), which meant I had to deal with the same classmates and same 
teachers year after fucking year. The teachers were depressed and fed up 
with the school going broke all the time from spending all their resources 
on buildings that were scrapped halfway through laying the foundation and 
the students just didn't bother getting decent grades. So you know what we 
did? Learned our shit from other stuff outside the classroom. Although I 
didn't go to Univeristy, I instead took up carpentry.﻿

comments.author: blazebluebass

comments.text:
This hit close to the bone. I was with my mom, visiting my Grandmother in 
hospital (who was losing her mind at the time); in the elevator, my mom 
looked at me and said "You're smart enough, you could have been a doctor, 
IF you applied yourself in high school". 

And I said, "Yeah mom - I was way out of line getting my MBA."

Lesson - sometimes, you just can't compete. And puss isn't worth dealing 
with.﻿

I always seem to find these videos when i'm having a major crisis, and they

comments.author: 16catmarie

comments.text:
School is the most of important thing in my life right now, but also the 
number one cause of my stress (along with everything else a teen goes 
through). Nothing comes before it and I can't remember the last day I 
haven't felt so frustrated. And what makes it worse is that I'm fully aware 
of how much harder it's going to get. What goes through my head is that I'm 
not going to get anywhere if I don't get the best grades. I have straight 
A's, my heart drops when I get a single B. I don't even know where I'm 
going either. People constantly ask me where I'm going in life and that's 
probably the hardest question I've been asked. Not knowing has often made 
me think about just giving up. I'm exhausted. Then I discovered 
vlogbrothers at the back of one of the books. This is the first video I've 
watched by them, and I feel like I've just been slapped in the face. The 
fact "High School is not Destiny" makes me realize how much of other things 
there are out there for me to pay attention to...and I wish I've known that 
so much sooner. All of that must have sounded dramatic, this is me just 
thanking John for opening my eyes with a single quote. This video has made 
my day, and probably my life.﻿

Thanks for making this video.﻿

comments.author: Omnos Dovah

comments.text:
This is so important, and knowing that I have ADHD and bipolar disorder, 
and having just read a tweet by John saying like many of people he takes 
psychiatric meds, and knowing that we both love writing and both of our 
writings have been praised by people (although I've never been published) 
and seeing his energy and enthusiasm when he says high school isn't 
destiny, I feel safe to say we're the same person, just experiencing life 
differently through different bodies... actually, that probably sounds nuts 
but I'm just being metaphorical and poetic here. I'm not saying I believe 
we're the same person for reals. But I will say this to all the high 
schoolers. I'm in graduate school and I almost flunked out of high school. 
That being said, you still need to work hard in high school because it's a 
good work ethic to get into and it will be easier to get into college if 
you can show how hard you work. Don't slack off. But don't think high 
school is the end all be all of life.﻿

comments.text:
Thanks so much for the destiny spiel at the end there. I'm graduating from 
high school in a couple of months and though it may sound silly, I was 
very, very sad about not being valedictorian. I work really hard and I just 
feel like my best efforts never get me anywhere. Thank you for sharing your 
story and giving me hope!﻿
comments.author: Sarah Hegerhorst

comments.text:
I feel that high school cannot be as emphasized as it is today. There are 
just too many ways that teenagers by no intention of their own can behave 
that makes high school a significant decision point in life. Many teenager 
like myself cannot reliably get to sleep on time, so we arrive at school 
feeling awful. Many students have identity crises, battling mental illness 
and are facing huge amounts of social pressure. Many students are 
struggling with the body of an adult but not the freedom, so they invent 
their own freedoms, notably drugs/cigarettes/tobacco. Many are naturally 
finding romance, and often our minds cannot make many choices to put much 
of anything not absolutely needed for survival, IE oxygen, water, food, 
above their significant other. This interferes with education.  ﻿

I was a crap kid all throughout school. The standardized tests said I was 
smart but I skipped class, I did bare minimum homework to pass and would 
half ass english assignments to give more time to my personal writing. I 
never bought into high school being the most important thing ever so I 
didn't care. I knew I had no choice but to start at community college so 
that probably contributed to my not giving a damn in high school. I went to 
college and straightened my act up and am graduating early and probably 
wouldn't change a thing. ﻿
comments.author: sodapoplove95

comments.text:
First off, I love how you did this! Looking back at the comments left from 
your teachers! I didn't even think of that! I just came across your video, 
as I just did my video a couple days ago and it showed up in my related 
videos. My video looks more at the self reflection of who I was, and how it 
shaped me into the person I am today. If you can please take a couple 
minutes to watch it, you'll see that I really am passionate when looking 
back at myself. Thank you for taking the time to read this and I hope to 
interact with you on my video! ﻿
